questions.text: The most common heart defect in congenital rubella syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) PDA

 

Explanation: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS).

 

Cardiac anomalies are observed in 50% of children infected during the first 8 weeks of gestation. The incidence of heart defects in congenital rubella syndrome follows this order:
PDA > PS (right > left) > VSD > ASD.

 

Etiology

Associated Heart Defects (Order)

Infections

Rubella Virus (German Measles)

Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA) > Pulmonary Artery Stenosis > Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) / Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Infection

Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) > Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) > Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)

Toxoplasmosis

Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) > Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)

Metabolic Defects

Maternal Diabetes

Transposition of the Great Vessels (TGV) > Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) / Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)

Genetic Disorders

Down Syndrome (Trisomy 21)

Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD) > Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) > Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA)

Turner Syndrome (45,X)

Coarctation of the Aorta > Bicuspid Aortic Valve > Aortic Stenosis

Noonan Syndrome

Pulmonary Stenosis > Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) > Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

Williams Syndrome

Supravalvular Aortic Stenosis (SVAS) > Pulmonary Artery Stenosis > Aortic Stenosis

DiGeorge Syndrome (22q11.2 Deletion)

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) > Interrupted Aortic Arch > Truncus Arteriosus

Drugs

Thalidomide

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) > Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) > Pulmonary Artery Stenosis

Lithium

Ebstein Anomaly > Atrial Septal Defect (ASD)

questions.text: An HIV-positive mother with a viral load of 1200 copies/mL delivers a baby. What is the most appropriate antiretroviral prophylaxis for the newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Nevirapine + Zidovudine for 6 weeks

  • In this case, the maternal viral load is 1200 copies/mL, hence, the infant is considered high risk, and since the mother’s treatment is not known, dual prophylaxis with Nevirapine + Zidovudine for 6 weeks is aimed at covering both intrapartum and early postpartum exposure.
  • Nevirapine (NVP) — NNRTI that inhibits reverse transcriptase, preventing viral replication soon after exposure.
  • Zidovudine (AZT) — NRTI that interferes with viral DNA synthesis, offering a complementary mechanism.
  • The dual regimen is more effective than single-drug prophylaxis in reducing perinatal HIV transmission in babies born to mothers with detectable viremia.
  • Early infant diagnosis with HIV DNA PCR at 6 weeks is mandatory.

Nevirapine for 6 weeks (Option A): Reserved for truly low-risk infants (maternal viral load <50 copies/mL close to delivery).

Nevirapine for 12 weeks (Option C): Used for high-risk breastfed infants when the mother is not virally suppressed.

Zidovudine for 4 weeks (Option D): Older protocol, no longer preferred in detectable maternal viral load scenarios per updated Indian recommendations.

questions.text: Congenital rubella syndrome has all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hydrocephalus:

  • Hydrocephalus is not a typical feature of Congenital Rubella Syndrome. The primary manifestations are sensorineural deafness, cataract, and cardiac defects.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Sensorineural deafness: Sensorineural deafness is a common feature of Congenital Rubella Syndrome.

Option B - Cataract: Cataract is another manifestation observed in infants with CRS.

Option C - Cardiac defects: Cardiac defects, particularly patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and pulmonary artery stenosis, are commonly associated with Congenital Rubella Syndrome.

questions.text: What is the rare and hazardous complication associated with Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Measles

Explanation:

  • Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis is a rare fatal, severe, long-standing complication of measles. It is a progressive neurological disorder that affects the central nervous system. It typically develops 7-13 years after primary measles infection.
     

Complications of Measles:

  • Otitis media (m/c complication), Pneumonia (m/c cause of death), other respiratory complications - bronchitis, laryngitis, etc.
  • Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE): Rare, fatal and long term complication.
  • Acute encephalitis

 

Prevention

  • Measles is a preventable and potentially eradicable disease.
  • Maternal antibodies protect infants until 6-9 months of age, so administering the vaccine at 9 months in endemic countries ensures early protection and seroconversion.
  • The measles vaccine, derived from the Edmonston-Zagreb strain, is available as a monovalent preparation or in combination with rubella (MR), mumps (MMR), and varicella (MMR-V).
  • The vaccine schedule is as follows:

Vaccine

MR (Measles-Rubella)

Type

Live attenuated

Dose

0.5 ml

Site

Anterolateral thigh or right upper arm (at the insertion of deltoid)

Schedule

1st dose - 9 months; 2nd dose - 16-24 months

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy, as shown in the image, presents with fever and painful sores in the mouth, along with a rash on his hand. Which of the following is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- Coxsackie virus

Explanation:

The characteristic presentation of fever accompanied by painful oral sores and hand rash is the classic triad of Hand Foot Mouth Disease.

Coxsackie virus, particularly type A16, is the causative agent of this condition.

Hand Foot Mouth Disease (HFMD)

Causative organism

Coxsackie A16 virus, Enterovirus 71

Age group

<5 years

Clinical features
  • Low grade fever, feeling of being unwell, sore throat are commonly observed.
  • Characterized by papulovesicular skin rash commonly on buttocks, knees, elbows and genital area.
  • Ulcers/blisters are also seen in the oral cavity, mostly on the posterior aspect.

Management

  • Resolves on its own in 5-7 days, till then symptomatic and conservative treatment is given.
  • Isolation of affected children at home and promotion of hand hygiene to prevent disease spread is important. 

Incorrect Options:

Pox virus (Option A): While pox viruses can cause skin lesions, they typically present with pustular lesions rather than the papulovesicular rash characteristic of HFMD.

HHV 7 virus (Option C): Human Herpesvirus 7 causes roseola infantum (6th disease), characterized by fever and maculopapular rash that begins on the trunk and spreads to the extremities. It does not cause oral sores or the characteristic hand lesions seen in this case.

HIV virus (Option D): While HIV can cause various skin manifestations, it does not present with oral sores along with the typical hand rash as seen in the patient, which is more consistent with HFMD.

questions.text: What would be the most appropriate course of action for the care of child Ajay, the 3-year-old brother of Anuj, who resides in the same household and received diphtheria vaccination approximately 16 months ago, while Anuj is currently undergoing treatment for diphtheria in the ward?

choices.text: Nothing, as the child is already exposed

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Erythromycin only

Explanation:

In situations where there is a known case of diphtheria in the household, it is recommended to administer erythromycin to individuals who have been in close contact with the infected person. Since Ajay, the younger sibling, has not developed symptoms but has been exposed, administering erythromycin alone is appropriate to prevent the development of the infection.

Diphtheria - Management of contacts

Asymptomatic Case Contacts
  • Includes household members and close contacts.
  • Monitored for 7 days for symptoms.
  • Prophylaxis: IM benzathine penicillin G (600,000 units for <6 years, 1,200,000 units for ≥6 years) or 10-day oral erythromycin (40- 50 mg/kg/day, max 2 g/day).
  • Assess and update immunization status.
  • Booster Dose: Administer the diphtheria toxoid vaccine to individuals who have not received a booster within the past 5 years.
  • Vaccinate children who have not yet received their 4th dose of diphtheria toxoid.
  • Incomplete or Uncertain Immunization: For those who have received fewer than 3 doses of diphtheria toxoid or have an uncertain immunization status, provide the vaccine according to the primary immunization schedule with an age-appropriate preparation

Asymptomatic Carriers
  • Receive 10-14 days of antimicrobial prophylaxis (oral erythromycin).
  • Administer diphtheria toxoid vaccine if no booster has been given in the past year.
  • Droplet precautions for respiratory carriers; contact precautions for cutaneous carriers.
  • Precautions continue until two negative cultures (24 hours apart) post-treatment.
  • Antitoxin is not recommended for asymptomatic carriers.

Follow-up & Repeat Cultures
  • Repeat cultures for cases and carriers 2 weeks post treatment.
  • If positive, repeat a 10 day erythromycin course and further cultures.
  • Complete eradication is not guaranteed after one course of antibiotics.

Casual Contacts
  • Routine investigation is not recommended due to low carriage rates.

Hospital-Acquired Transmission
  • Rare; only those with direct contact with respiratory/oral secretions need management as contacts.

While one booster dose (Option A) of the diphtheria vaccine is generally recommended as part of routine immunization schedules, it is not the next best step in this case. As the child is 3 years old, he would have received the 4th dose (1st booster dose) of diphtheria vaccine between 16- 24 months of age. Since he has received a booster dose in the last 5 years, only Erythromycin is needed in this patient.

Nothing as the child is already exposed (Option B): Even though the younger sibling has received vaccination against diphtheria 16 months ago, it does not ensure complete protection or eliminate the risk of infection. Vaccination provides immunity, but it may not be 100% effective in preventing infection. Therefore, appropriate measures should be taken to minimize the risk of transmission and potential illness.

Administering both erythromycin and diphtheria toxoid (Option C) is not the recommended next step in this case. In the case of the younger sibling who has not developed symptoms, administration of erythromycin alone is sufficient as a preventive measure.

questions.text: Which maternal antibodies do not confer substantial immunity in a newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Polio

Explanation:

In polio, maternal antibodies do not provide significant immunity to the neonate. This is because the transfer of polio-specific antibodies from the mother to the fetus is limited and the protection offered by these antibodies against polio infection is not as robust.

Poliovirus (Family: Picornaviridae)

  • Transmission: Fecal-oral route
  • Incubation Period: 8-12 days from exposure to the onset of symptoms.
  • It has three serotypes: PV1, PV2, and PV3
  • Pathogenesis: The virus spreads from the intestinal tract to the central nervous system (CNS), potentially causing aseptic meningitis and poliomyelitis.
  • Poliomyelitis often leads to flaccid paralysis because it primarily affects the anterior horn cells in the spinal cord, which are responsible for motor control resulting in muscle weakness and atrophy.
  • Reflexes may be diminished or absent due to the disruption of the motor neurons.
  • Types of Poliovirus Infections:

Inapparent Infection

90-95% of cases; asymptomatic

Abortive Poliomyelitis

Mild, flu-like symptoms with full recovery

Nonparalytic Poliomyelitis

More severe symptoms, including neck stiffness and pain, with a good prognosis

Paralytic Poliomyelitis

Includes spinal, bulbar, and polio encephalitis forms, presenting with various degrees of paralysis
  • Diagnosis:
    • Consider polio in any unimmunised child with acute flaccid paralysis, particularly in areas with past or current polio cases.
    • Isolation of poliovirus from stool specimens collected 24-48 hours apart.
  • Management: Supportive care is primary; ventilatory support may be necessary for severe respiratory involvement.
  • Prevention (Vaccination):
    • Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV): Live attenuated vaccine administered orally that induces both systemic & mucosal immunity with a risk of vaccine-associated polio.
    • Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV): Killed virus vaccine. Given via injection that provides systemic immunity without the risk of vaccine-derived polio.

Maternal antibodies formed from Tdap vaccination during pregnancy will provide immunity against tetanus (Option A), diphtheria (Option C), and pertussis in the newborn. Administering the Tdap vaccine earlier, between the 27th and 36th week of gestation, maximizes the transfer of passive antibodies to the infant.

Maternal antibodies generally protect infants less than 6 months from measles (Option D).

questions.text: What would be your diagnosis for a 3-year-old male who has the given buccal mucosa findings and subsequently develops a rash after three days?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Measles

Explanation:

The image shows Koplik’s spot on the buccal mucosa, which is pathognomonic of measles. Koplik's spots are small, white spots with a bluish-white centre and red halo that appear on the buccal mucosa.

Aspects

Description

Causative agent

Measles (rubeola) is a highly communicable childhood exanthematous illness caused by the measles virus, an RNA virus from the Paramyxoviridae family.

Transmission

Contact with droplet aerosols (through the respiratory tract or conjunctiva)

Pathogenesis

Primary viremia occurs, resulting in infection of the reticuloendothelial system, followed by secondary viremia, which results in systemic symptoms.

Incubation period

8-12 days

Period of infectivity

From 3 days before to 4 days after the rash onset.

Clinical manifestations
  • Common in preschool children
  • Prodromal phase: Fever (before rash), rhinorrhea, conjunctival congestion and a dry hacking cough.
  • Koplik spots, pathognomonic for measles, appear on the 2nd or 3rd day of illness as grey-white, sand-like lesions with surrounding erythema on the buccal mucosa opposite the lower second molars.

Rash

The erythematous maculopapular rash in measles appears on the 4th day, starting behind the ears, along the hairline, and posterior cheeks, then spreading to the rest of the body over the next 2-3 days.

Management

Symptomatic and conservative (antipyretics, maintenance of hygiene, ensuring adequate fluid and caloric intake, and humidification).

Vitamin A reduces the morbidity and mortality of measles.

 

Leukoplakia (Option B) appears as a white patch in the oral cavity that cannot be wiped off.

Scarlet fever (Option C) is group A Streptococcal (GAS) pharyngitis and is characterized by a distinctive sandpaper rash. The rash appears as a diffuse, finely papular, erythematous eruption that turns the skin bright red and blanches on pressure. It starts around the neck and spreads to the trunk and extremities and strawberry tongue is also seen.

Kawasaki disease (Option D) is a systemic inflammatory disorder with arteritis of medium to large-sized vessels. It presents with fever, rash (maculopapular, erythema multiforme), conjunctivitis, and cervical lymph nodes and strawberry tongue is also seen.

questions.text: What guidance should be provided to the students who have been exposed to meningococcal meningitis, considering that two girls in their class have been diagnosed with the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Antibiotic prophylaxis

Explanation:

Meningococcal meningitis is a bacterial infection that can spread through close contact with respiratory and throat secretions of an infected person. It is important to take precautions to prevent the spread of the disease among other students by taking antibiotic prophylaxis. Antibiotics can be given to individuals who have been in close contact with someone diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis to help prevent the spread of the bacteria.

Chemoprophylaxis following meningococcal exposure:

Close contacts warranting chemoprophylaxis:

  • Household contacts (including persons who ate or slept in the same dwelling as the patient during the 7 days prior to disease onset)
  • Child-care and nursery-school contacts
  • Persons having contact with patient’s oral secretions during the 7 days prior to disease onset:
    • Sharing of toothbrushes
    • Sharing of eating utensils
    • Mouth-to-mouth resuscitation
    • Kissing
    • Unprotected contact during endotracheal intubation
  • Aircraft contacts for persons seated next to the patient for > 8 hrs

Prophylaxis is provided to contacts within 24 hours of identification of the index case. The antibiotics effective include

  • Rifampicin - 600 mg 12 hourly for 2 days
  • Ciprofloxacin - 500 mg single dose
  • Azithromycin - 500 mg single dose
  • Ceftriaxone - 250 mg Intramuscular single dose

Vaccines are available for most meningococcal subgroups but not group B, which is one of the most common serogroups isolated in many countries

Persons at low risk in whom chemoprophylaxis is not recommended

  • Casual contact (e.g. at school or work) without direct exposure to the patient’s oral secretions
  • Indirect contact only (contact with a high-risk contact and not a case)
  • Health-care worker without direct exposure to patient’s oral secretions

questions.text: A neonate on examination has bilateral cataracts and, after investigations, is found to have a patent ductus arteriosus and salt & paper retinopathy. What is the most likely congenital infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Rubella

Explanation:

The patent ductus arteriosus, bilateral cataracts, and salt & pepper retinopathy are classical signs of congenital rubella syndrome.

Congenital Rubella
  • Rubella (German measles) is a mild disease in infants and children but can cause congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) if contracted during pregnancy.
  • The risk is highest in the first trimester, especially within the first 8 weeks.

Pathogenesis

  • Viremia is most intense from 10 to 17 days after infection.
  • Viral shedding is from day 10 of infection up to 2 weeks.

Risk of Defects by Gestational Age
  • Highest in the first 12 weeks of gestation and decreases significantly thereafter, with defects being rare after 20 weeks.

Clinical features of congenital rubella syndrome
  • Hearing loss (most common)
  • Vision problems (cataracts, glaucoma, salt and pepper retinopathy).
    • Cataracts are the most common ocular abnormality associated with congenital rubella.

  • Heart defects (patent ductus arteriosus > pulmonary artery stenosis (right > left) > ventricular septal defect)
  • Low birth weight
  • Neurological issues (microcephaly, intellectual disabilities, encephalitis, behavioural issues)

Chronicity and Complications
  • Chronic presence of the virus can cause ongoing damage
  • The risk of progressive rubella panencephalitis (PRP) years later is a rare complication.
  • Less common complications: Growth retardation, hepatitis, bone lesions.
  • Risk of diabetes and thyroid dysfunction

Diagnosis
  • Rubella IgM enzyme immunosorbent assay (detects antibodies)
  • Viral isolation (growing the virus from samples)
  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) (detects viral RNA)

Management
  • No specific treatment for CRS; supportive care is key
  • Early intervention for complications (e.g., hearing loss) is crucial

Prevention
  • Standard with droplet precaution in hospitalized cases
  • Rubella vaccination RA 27/3 live attenuated vaccine (MMR or MMRV with varicella) effectively prevents rubella and CRS
  • MMR vaccine has a 95% efficacy after one dose and 99% after two doses
  • Vaccination side effects: fever, rash, joint pain

Considerations for Pregnant Women
  • Immunoglobulin may be considered if pregnancy is not terminated, though it does not guarantee prevention of fetal infection

Congenital CMV infection (Option B) is usually asymptomatic at birth. If symptomatic, these neonates present with jaundice, petechiae, hepatosplenomegaly, microcephaly, and chorioretinitis.

Congenital toxoplasmosis (Option C) caused by Toxoplasma gondii often presents with the classic triad of intracranial calcifications, hydrocephalus, and chorioretinitis

Congenital varicella (Option D) presents with cicatricial zigzag skin scarring in a dermatomal pattern, limb hypoplasia, microcephaly, seizures, mental retardation, chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, cataracts, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations would be most beneficial in diagnosing the condition of a 10-year-old boy who is experiencing seizures along with a medical history of fever accompanied by a rash at the age of 1 year, which was resolved on its own?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - lgG measles in CSF:

  • The child's history of fever with rash at 1 year of age, which resolved spontaneously, suggests a possible previous measles infection.

Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare complication of measles that can occur years after a measles infection. In SSPE, there is persistent measles virus infection in the central nervous system, leading to inflammation and progressive neurological deterioration. To diagnose SSPE, the presence of elevated measles-specific IgG antibodies in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) is considered a helpful investigation. IgG antibodies are produced in response to previous infection and can persist in the CSF for an extended period.

Complications of Measles: Complications of measles are more frequent in the young, malnourished and immunocompromised individuals.

  • Otitis media (most common complication)
  • Pneumonia (most common cause of death)
  • Other respiratory complications - bronchitis, laryngitis, etc.
  • Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis (SSPE): rare, fatal (most common long term complication.
  • Acute encephalitis

Prevention of Measles:

  • Measles is a preventable and potentially eradicable disease.
  • Maternal antibodies protect infants until 6-9 months of age, so administering the vaccine at 9 months in endemic countries ensures early protection and seroconversion.
  • The measles vaccine, derived from the Edmonston-Zagreb strain, is available as a monovalent preparation or in combination with rubella (MR), mumps (MMR), and varicella (MMR-V).
  • The vaccination schedule is as follows:

Vaccine

MR (Measles-Rubella)

Type

Live attenuated

Dose

0.5 ml

Site

Right upper arm (at the insertion of deltoid)

Schedule

1st dose - 9 months; 2nd dose - 16-24 months

MRI mesial temporal lobe sclerosis (Option B) is a specific finding on MRI associated with temporal lobe epilepsy. It is characterized by atrophy and abnormal signal intensity in the mesial temporal structures, particularly the hippocampus.

The detection of lgM measles in CSF (Option C) may indicate recent or ongoing measles infection. However, in the case of SSPE, the initial measles infection usually occurred several years before the onset of symptoms. Therefore, the presence of IgM antibodies in CSF is not helpful in diagnosing SSPE.

C1Q4 antibodies in the CSF (Option D) are not associated with SSPE or measles infection. These antibodies are typically associated with certain autoimmune diseases, such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby was brought to the hospital with complaints of poor feeding and abnormal twitching of his lower limbs. On examination, he has fever with fontanelle bulging, and the child was lethargic. The most probable cause is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Meningitis


Explanation: The clinical features of poor feeding, fever, bulging fontanelle, lethargy, and abnormal twitching of his lower limb (seizure) strongly suggest meningitis.

 

Bacterial Meningitis:

  • Etiological agents:
 

In India

Overall

Neonates

Gram-negative organisms

(E.Coli > Acinetobacter > Klebsiella)

Group B streptococci

Infants and older children

Streptococcus Pneumoniae >

Neisseria Meningitidis > Haemophilus influenzae.

Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

  • Risk Factors for Bacterial Meningitis:
  1. Lack of preexisting immunity
  2. Close Contact with infected individuals
  3. Crowding
  4. Low Socioeconomic Factors
  5. Congenital or Acquired CSF Leak
  6. Cochlear Implant

 

Category

Clinical Manifestations

Nonspecific Findings
  • Fever, anorexia, poor feeding
  • Headache, upper respiratory symptoms
  • Myalgias, arthralgias
  • Tachycardia, hypotension
  • Cutaneous signs: Petechiae, purpura, or erythematous macular rash

Meningeal Irritation
  • Nuchal rigidity
  • Back pain
  • Kernig sign: Pain with extension of the leg after hip flexion
  • Brudzinski sign: Involuntary flexion of the knees and hips upon neck flexion

Increased Intracranial Pressure (ICP) Signs
  • Headache, emesis
  • Bulging fontanel or diastasis of sutures
  • Cranial nerve involvement: anisocoria, ptosis, abducens nerve paralysis
  • Hypertension with bradycardia, apnea, or hyperventilation
  • Decorticate or decerebrate posturing, stupor, coma, or herniation signs
  • Papilledema

Focal Neurologic Signs
  • Seizures
  • Altered mental status
  • Photophobia
  • Tâche cérébrale: Raised red streak appearing 30-60 seconds after stroking the skin with a blunt object

 

  • Diagnosis:
    • Lumbar puncture and CSF analysis: Gold standard.
    • CSF shows Neutrophilic pleocytosis, increased proteins and decreased glucose.
  • Treatment:
    • Antibiotics: Third-generation cephalosporins (Ceftriaxone) x 10 to 14 days
    • Steroids: Inj. Dexamethasone started 1-2 hr before antibiotics and continued for 48 hrs - Prevents cytokine-mediated CNS injury.

 

Febrile seizures (Option A) typically occur in response to fever, but in the absence of other features of central nervous system infection like bulging fontanelle, poor feeding, and lethargy, they are less likely to be the cause. These symptoms suggest a more severe condition like meningitis.

 

Pseudotumor cerebri (Option C) is a rare condition in children under 10 years old and is often associated with obesity, female gender, and certain medications (like lithium, tetracyclines, steroid withdrawal and hypervitaminosis A). It presents with increased intracranial pressure but does not typically cause fever, bulging fontanelle, or abnormal twitching. It usually has a chronic course and presents with papilledema in most cases.

 

Intracranial hemorrhage (Option D) can lead to seizures or abnormal movements, it generally presents with more pronounced neurological deficits such as altered consciousness, focal neurological findings, or altered tone, and is less likely to cause fever and bulging fontanelle, which are more indicative of meningitis.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and vesicular lesions on the upper and lower limbs. Neck stiffness was present. Similar lesions were present on the palms, soles, and oral cavity. CSF analysis revealed normal glucose levels and elevated lymphocytes and protein. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth disease


Explanation:

The given clinical presentation and images are suggestive of Coxsackie viral meningitis and Hand Foot Mouth Disease (HFMD) caused by the Coxsackie A16 virus.

 

The fever and neck stiffness with CSF examination showing normal glucose level and elevated protein and lymphocytes is suggestive of viral meningitis.

Hand Foot Mouth Disease (HFMD)

Causative organism

Coxsackie A16 virus and Enterovirus A71

Age group

<5 years

Clinical features
  • Low-grade fever, feeling of being unwell, and sore throat are commonly observed.
  • Characterized by papulovesicular skin rash commonly on buttocks, knees, elbows, around the mouth, and genital area.
  • Ulcers/blisters are also seen in the oral cavity, mostly on the posterior aspect
 

Management 
  • Resolves on its own in 5-7 days, till then symptomatic and conservative treatment is given.
  • Isolation of affected children at home and promotion of hand hygiene to prevent disease spread is important.

Bacterial meningitis with sepsis (Option A) presents with cutaneous signs like petechiae, purpura or erythema and not with maculopapular lesions.


Herpes simplex gingivostomatitis and meningoencephalitis (Option C): Herpes gingivostomatitis is a very painful condition that presents with sudden onset of pain in the mouth, drooling, refusal to eat or drink, and fever. The oral lesions begin as hyperemia of the mucosa to rapidly spreading vesicles that ulcerate and eventually rupture. Herpes meningoencephalitis is an acute necrotizing infection and presents with fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, vomiting, etc. This is not the given clinical scenario.


Tuberculous meningitis (Option D) is a serious condition that can be fatal, and the child occasionally has a history of TB. The rupture of the tubercles (Rich’s foci) in the brain leads to this condition and may present with acute hydrocephalus, seizures, and cerebral oedema. These do not align with the clinical scenario given.

questions.text: Which of the following is given as a part of the therapy for a child with severe COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Corticosteroids

Explanation:

In case of severe COVID, where SpO2 < 90%, due to inflammatory damage to alveoli, the corticosteroid is administered to reduce inflammation and improve oxygenation.


 

Treatment Protocols for COVID-19

 

 

Mild Disease
  • Home Management & Hydration
  • Medications: Use paracetamol for fever and nasal saline drops for congestion.
  • Avoid antibiotics and multivitamins (no proven benefit).
  • Monitoring: Watch for red flag signs like rapid breathing, oxygen saturation below 95%, persistent fever, lethargy, or poor feeding.
 

Moderate Disease
  • Admit to Covid ward
  • SpO2 > 94: Hydration, paracetamol and antimicrobials
  • SpO2 < 94: Oxygen, IV Steroids, Remdesivir, Antimicrobials
 

Severe/Critical

  • Covid - 19 ICU / HDU ward
  • Oxygen, CPAP, Invasive ventilation if required
  • IV corticosteroids, Remdesivir (controversial) , Enoxaparin, Antimicrobials
  • Manage Shock, ARDS, AKI, and Myocarditis as per protocol

 

  • Steroids: Administer IV dexamethasone at 0.15 mg/kg (max 6 mg) once daily for 5-14 days.
  • Remdesivir should be administered only in a hospital setting.
  • Enoxaparin:
    • For <2 months: 1.5 mg/kg/dose every 12 hours.
    • For >2 months: 1 mg/kg/dose every 12 hours.


Ivermectin (Option B) was earlier thought to have antiviral properties, but evidence shows there is no decrease in mortality and hospital stay. Hence it is not recommended to be used for COVID-19.


There is controversy in the use of Remdesivir (Option C) between guidelines given by IAP and MoHFW. As per IAP, Remdesivir can be used at more than 1 month of age, for moderate to severe COVID-19 disease in hospital settings. However, as per MOHFW, remdesivir is not recommended in children. There is a lack of sufficient evidence on safety and efficacy concerning Remdesivir in children below 18 years of age.

questions.text: Which of the statements below accurately describes congenital CMV infection?

choices.text: About 20-30% of the infections are symptomatic
Triad of SNHL, periventricular calcification and enamel hypoplasia
Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop conductive hearing loss later in life
If the mother is lgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop an infection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) If the mother is lgG positive for CMV, the child is unlikely to develop an infection.



Explanation:

IgG antibodies can cross the placenta and provide passive immunity to infants. In the case of congenital CMV infection, if the mother was previously infected and is IgG positive, she would provide passive immunity to the fetus thus making it unlikely for the fetus to develop an infection.


 

Congenital CMV infection can be described as follows:

 

Human cytomegalovirus (CMV)

Mode of Transmission
  • Bodily fluids: saliva, urine, blood, vaginal fluids, breast milk
  • Community exposure: Daycare centres
  • Perinatal exposure: During birth
  • Breastfeeding

Risk of Transmission
  • 30% of women with primary CMV infection during pregnancy transmit the virus to the fetus.
  • In-utero infections also occur in previously immune women but at a reduced rate

Transmission by Gestational Age

Transmission rates are higher following a primary infection, with the risk increasing as gestational age advances.

Clinical Features of congenital CMV infection
  • Asymptomatic Infection (90% of infected newborns): No signs at birth; detected through newborn screening.
  • Symptomatic Infection (10% of infected newborns (vs Option A)):
    • Jaundice (direct bilirubin >2 mg/dL)
    • Petechiae (small, red, or purple spots on the skin) giving a blueberry muffin appearance
    • Hepatosplenomegaly
    • Microcephaly
    • Intrauterine growth restriction
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Purpura (3% infants) (larger areas of bleeding under the skin)
  • Less Common Findings:
    • Hearing loss (M/c long-term consequence; may develop later).
  • Lab findings align with the clinical presentation: Direct hyperbilirubinemia, ￪ ALT, thrombocytopenia, and Head CT abnormalities


Triad of SNHL, periventricular calcification and enamel hypoplasia (seen in congenital syphilis) (Option C) is not seen in congenital CMV infection. It presents with jaundice, petechiae (blueberry muffin rash), microcephaly, SNHL, chorioretinitis, periventricular calcification, and hepatosplenomegaly.


Most children asymptomatic at birth can develop conductive hearing loss later in life (Option D): This is a false statement since this pattern is seen in late-onset congenital syphilis.

questions.text: A child presents with complaints of fever, rash, body ache, and throat ache. He has a history of thorn prick injury a week back. What antibiotics would you give empirically to this child?
questions.solution:
The child's presentation of fever, rash, body ache, and throat ache, along with a history of thorn prick injury, points towards a likely diagnosis of scarlet fever. Amoxicillin + clavulanate is the preferred empirical antibiotic as it provides effective coverage for Group A Streptococcus, the most common cause of scarlet fever.

Scarlet Fever

Group A Streptococcus (GAS) pharyngitis is associated with a characteristic rash caused due to a pyrogenic exotoxin (erythrogenic toxin) produced by GAS in individuals lacking antitoxin antibodies.

Caused By

Group A Streptococcus (GAS)

Incidence and Virulence

Less common and less virulent now compared to the past, with incidence depending on toxin strains and the population immunity.

Clinical Features
  • Rash appears within 24-48 hours, starting around the neck and spreading to the trunk and extremities.
  • Rash is a diffuse, finely papular, erythematous eruption causing bright-red discoloration, which blanches on pressure.
  • Rash is accentuated in the creases of the elbow, axilla, and groin (Pastia lines) and gives the skin a goose-pimple appearance.
  • Erythematous cheeks with pallor around the mouth.
  • After 3-4 days, the rash fades, followed by desquamation starting on the face and progressing downward.
  • Desquamation may occur around fingernails, palms, and soles.
  • Tongue is coated with swollen papillae, which later give a "strawberry tongue" appearance after desquamation.
  • Pharyngitis.

Diagnosis
  • Classic scarlet fever is typically straightforward to diagnose.
  • A history of recent exposure to GAS is helpful.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying GAS in the pharynx.

Treatment

  • Antibiotic therapy should be started immediately.
  • Drug of choice: Penicillin or amoxicillin for 10 days.
  • Alternative for Penicillin Allergy: Oral cephalosporins, clindamycin, Macrolides (erythromycin, clarithromycin) for 10 days or azalide (azithromycin) for 5 days.
  • Injection: Benzathine penicillin G single dose intramuscular injection for those unlikely to complete oral therapy.

Complication

  • Suppurative Complications:
    • Cervical lymphadenitis
    • Peritonsillar abscess
    • Retropharyngeal abscess
    • Otitis media
    • Mastoiditis
    • Sinusitis
    • Group A Streptococcus (GAS) pneumonia
  • Nonsuppurative Complications:
    • Acute rheumatic fever
    • Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

questions.text: An unvaccinated 5-year-old child of a migrant worker family was brought to the causality with fever and a characteristic skin rash. Upon eye examination, Bitot’s spot was seen. What is the appropriate management?

choices.text: Isolate and give nutritional supply with vitamin A supplement
Give measles vaccine and vitamin A supplement
Institutional Isolation, nutritional management with vitamin A supplement

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Isolate and give nutritional supply with vitamin A supplement

Explanation:

The child has a fever and rash with cough and coryza with a non-immunised status which points to the diagnosis of measles. However, the presence of Bitot’s spot also shows vitamin A deficiency. Hence, the management here is isolation of the child, and nutritional management with vitamin A supplementation.

Aspects

Description

Causative agent

Measles (rubeola) is a highly communicable childhood exanthematous illness caused by the measles virus, an RNA virus from the Paramyxoviridae family.

Transmission

Contact with droplet aerosols (through the respiratory tract or conjunctiva)

Pathogenesis

Primary viremia occurs, resulting in infection of the reticuloendothelial system, followed by secondary viremia, which results in systemic symptoms.

Incubation period

8-12 days

Period of infectivity

From 3 days before to 4 days after the rash onset.

Clinical manifestations
  • Common in preschool children
  • Prodromal phase: Fever (before rash), rhinorrhea, conjunctival congestion and a dry hacking cough.
  • Koplik spots, pathognomonic for measles, appear on the 2nd or 3rd day of illness as grey-white, sand-like lesions with surrounding erythema on the buccal mucosa opposite the lower second molars.

Rash

The erythematous maculopapular rash in measles appears on the 4th day, starting behind the ears, along the hairline, and posterior cheeks, then spreading to the rest of the body over the next 2-3 days.

Management

Isolation.

Symptomatic and conservative (antipyretics, maintenance of hygiene, ensuring adequate fluid and caloric intake, and humidification).

Treatment of vitamin A deficiency:

Age Group

Treatment

Under 6 months

50,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and 4 weeks later

6 to 12 months

100,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and 4 weeks later

Over 1 year

200,000 IU once daily on D1, D2, and 4 weeks later

Giving a measles vaccine and vitamin A supplement (Option B) or only a measles vaccine (Option D) is not appropriate since the child is already suffering from measles.

Institutional Isolation, nutritional management and vitamin A supplement (Option C): Institutional isolation is unnecessary in this case since the child does not have any general danger signs, respiratory distress or pneumonia.

questions.text: A baby is born with microcephaly, intracerebral calcification and chorioretinitis. Which teratogenic infections is the mother suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Toxoplasma

Explanation:

The presence of characteristic intracranial calcifications, microcephaly, and chorioretinitis are features of congenital toxoplasmosis.

Etiology and Clinical Features of Congenital Toxoplasmosis:

Category

Details

Etiology

Primary maternal infection with Toxoplasma gondii during pregnancy is the primary cause

Risk Factors

Infection during the first trimester: severe outcomes, lower transmission rate (~17%)

Infection during third trimester: milder outcomes, higher transmission rate (~65%)

Clinical Features

CNS: Hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, seizures, developmental delays, microcephaly in severe brain damage

Ocular: Chorioretinitis, vision impairment, strabismus, photophobia, epiphora

Systemic: Hepatosplenomegaly, lymphadenopathy, prematurity

Other: Jaundice, thrombocytopenia, rash, hearing loss

Diagnosis:

Diagnosis Method

Details

Fetal Ultrasound

Performed every 2 weeks during gestation after diagnosis of maternal infection.

PCR Analysis of Amniotic Fluid

Used for prenatal diagnosis of fetal infection.

Serologic Tests

Persistent or rising titers in dye/IFA tests, positive IgM-ELISA.

Newborn Evaluation

General, ophthalmologic, and neurologic exams; head CT scan for intracranial calcifications.

CSF Analysis

Lumbar puncture with analysis for Toxoplasma-specific IgG and IgM, total IgG, cells, glucose, and protein.

Toxoplasma Isolation

Isolation from placenta, infant’s leukocytes, and CSF using PCR

Management:

Treatment

Details

Pyrimethamine and Sulfadiazine, along with Folinic Acid (Calcium Leucovorin)

Synergistic action against Toxoplasma gondii. Standard treatment for congenital toxoplasmosis. Folinic Acid is administered to prevent bone marrow suppression caused by pyrimethamine

Spiramycin

Used in pregnant women during the first trimester to prevent vertical transmission.

Monitoring

Regular leukocyte counts twice weekly to detect neutropenia and other hematologic effects.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) Infection (Option B) can also cause intracranial calcifications; however, these are more commonly seen in a periventricular pattern. While there is some overlap, the calcifications in congenital toxoplasmosis are often more diffuse.

Varicella (Option C) presents with microcephaly and chorioretinitis. But it is associated with microphthalmia, cataracts, cortical atrophy, seizures, mental retardation, etc. as well.

Rubella (Option D) presents with patent ductus arteriosus, bilateral cataracts, and salt & pepper retinopathy, which are classical signs of congenital rubella syndrome

questions.text: A 4-year-old unvaccinated child presents with fever, rash, and Bitot spots. What is the appropriate line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Only Vitamin A Supplementation

Explanation:

  • The child already has measles, so the priority is to address the vitamin A deficiency (as evidenced by Bitot spots) to reduce the risk of complications and support recovery.
  • The measles vaccine is not required at this stage because the child has already been infected and will develop lifelong immunity.

Measles

Causative agent
  • ssRNA paramyxovirus

Incubation period
  • 10 days from exposure to onset of fever and 14 days to the appearance of rash

Source of infection
  • Person with measles
  • Infective material

Period of communicability
  • 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of rash

Clinical features

Prodromal stage:

  • Fever
  • Cough
  • Coryza with sneezing
  • Conjunctivitis with lacrimation
  • Koplik’s spots- grayish-white spots on the buccal mucosa (Pathognomonic feature)
 

Eruptive stage:

  • Dusky red macular/maculopapular rash, which starts behind the ears and progresses to the face, neck and then to trunks and limbs.
  • In the absence of complications, the lesions and fever disappear after 3-4 days.
 

Post measles stage:

  • After the eruptive stage, it leads to weight loss, weakness, fatigue, diarrhea.

Isolation period
  • 7 days from the onset of rash

Difference between measles and rubella rash
  • Both rashes are maculopapular
  • The rash in measles is more confluent and botchy, whereas the rash in rubella is discrete or non-confluent.

Diagnosis
  • Clinically diagnosed based on rash and koplik’s spots
  • Gold standard: PCR

Treatment
  • No specific treatment
  • Symptomatic management only

Measles Rash

Measles Vaccine + Vitamin A Supplementation (Option A): The measles vaccine is not needed after measles infection, as the child will have lifelong immunity. The vaccine is for prevention, not for post-infection management.

Only Measles Vaccine (Option B): The vaccine is unnecessary post-infection, and vitamin A supplementation is critical in this case.

Supportive Care (Option D): While supportive care is part of the management, it does not address the important need for vitamin A supplementation in a measles case.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents with a rash, bleeding gums, and a positive tourniquet test. His platelet count is 25,000. Which of the following is the most important prognostic feature in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Low platelet count:

  • In this clinical scenario, the most important prognostic feature for the 3-year-old boy presenting with a rash, bleeding gums, and a positive tourniquet test, along with a platelet count of 25,000, is the low platelet count.
  • This is because a significantly low platelet count is directly associated with a higher risk of bleeding complications and is crucial for determining the management and prognosis of the condition.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Elevated total leukocyte count (TLC):

  • While an elevated TLC may indicate an underlying infection or inflammation, it is less directly related to the prognosis of bleeding risk compared to platelet count. In conditions with bleeding, the platelet count is a more immediate indicator of potential complications.

Option C - Hematocrit:

  • Hematocrit measures the proportion of blood volume occupied by red blood cells. While it can provide information on anemia or blood volume status, it is not the primary prognostic factor for bleeding disorders related to low platelet counts.

Option D - Peripheral smear:

  • A peripheral smear can reveal the morphology of blood cells and help in diagnosing various hematological conditions. However, in the context of immediate bleeding risk and prognosis, platelet count is more critical than the peripheral smear findings.

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child was brought to the OPD with complaints of low-grade fever, headache and mild upper respiratory tract symptoms for the last 4 days. On examination, an erythematous rash was found on the cheeks. The parents said the rash developed on the cheeks first and then spread out to involve his trunk and limbs. The causative agent of this disease has a single-stranded DNA. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Erythema infectiosum

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease), caused by Parvovirus B19, a single-stranded DNA virus (Parvoviridae family)
  • The disease presents with characteristic features, including low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory symptoms, followed by the distinctive "slapped cheek" appearance of facial erythema that spreads to involve the trunk and extremities in a lacy or reticulated pattern.
  • The progression of symptoms and the age of presentation (5 years) are classic for this self-limiting condition.

Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth disease)

Causative agent

Parvovirus B19

Age group affected

5 to 15 years (70% of cases)

Incubation period

4-28 days

Transmission

Respiratory droplets. Transmission rates among contacts are 15-30%.

Clinical features
  • Prodromal phase: Low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection symptoms.
  • The characteristic rash in this condition is a "slapped cheek appearance”, presenting as erythematous flushing on the face.
  • The erythematous rash spreads to the trunk and proximal extremities as a lacy or reticulated pattern.

 

Management

Self-limiting disease

Hand, foot and mouth disease (Option A): This condition is caused by Coxsackievirus A & Enterovirus71, types of ss-RNA virus from Picronaviridae family, and presents with vesicular lesions primarily on hands, feet, and mouth. The pattern and type of rash are different, and the causative agent is not a DNA virus.

Measles (Option B): Caused by a single-stranded RNA virus from Paramyxoviridae family, measles presents with high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a rash that begins behind the ears and spreads downward. The characteristic lesion Koplik spots (on buccal mucosa) appear on 1 day before onset of rash and persist for 2-3 days.

Rubella (Option D): caused by an ss-RNA virus from Togaviridae family, it presents with a fine, pink-red maculopapular rash that follows a descending pattern. Characteristic Forchheimer spots are a fleeting enanthem seen as small petechiae on the soft palate in 20% of patients with rubella. However, the virus type and the characteristic "slapped cheek" appearance are not features of rubella.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct about congenital CMV?

choices.text: 40-50% of the cases are symptomatic at birth
Optimum sample for PCR is blood/urine/saliva sample within 2-3 weeks of birth
If asymptomatic at birth, then there is a 25.7% higher risk of developing SNHL later
Most common congenital infection after congenital syphilis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Optimum sample for PCR is blood/urine/saliva sample within 2-3 weeks of birth

Explanation:

  • The correct statement is that the optimal sample for PCR in diagnosing congenital CMV infection is blood, urine, or saliva collected within the first 2-3 weeks of life. Testing after this period cannot reliably distinguish between congenital and acquired infection. Saliva and urine samples are more sensitive than blood because not all infants with congenital CMV are viremic at birth.

Congenital Cytomegalovirus (CMV)

Causative Agent

Cytomegalovirus (CMV), a member of the herpesvirus family

Transmission

Vertical transmission from mother to fetus during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding.

Incidence

CMV is the most common congenital viral infection, affecting approximately 0.5-2% of all live births.

Incubation Period

3–12 weeks

Risk Period

Highest fetal risk occurs when the mother contracts CMV during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester

Classical Triad

1. Sensorineural deafness

2. Microcephaly

3. Chorioretinitis

Clinical Features in Neonates

Asymptomatic in 80-90% of cases

 

Symptomatic in 10-20% of cases, with signs such as:

  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Petechial rash,
  • Microcephaly
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Seizures
  • Intracranial periventricular calcifications.

Long-Term Sequelae
  • Hearing loss (most common)
  • Developmental delay
  • Visual impairment (e.g., chorioretinitis)
  • Cerebral palsy
  • Seizure disorders

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting CMV DNA using PCR in urine, saliva, or blood collected within the first 2-3 weeks of life.
  • Preferred sample: Urine > saliva > blood
  • IgM antibody detection in fetal blood is less reliable.

Management

Ganciclovir or valganciclovir may be used in symptomatic infants with progressive neurologic disease or hearing loss.

Prognosis
  • Asymptomatic infants generally have a normal long-term outcome
  • Symptomatic infants may have developmental and neurological impairments

questions.text: Which of the following has the least risk of perinatal transmission?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rubella

Explanation:

  • Rubella (German measles) has the least risk of perinatal transmission among the options provided. Although rubella can cause significant intrauterine transmission, especially in the first trimester of pregnancy, its overall risk of perinatal transmission is lower compared to other infections.

 

Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS)

 

Causative Agent

Rubella virus

Transmission

Vertical transmission from mother to fetus during pregnancy; highest risk during the first trimester

Risk Period

Highest fetal risk occurs when the mother contracts rubella in the first trimester

Classical Triad

1. Sensorineural deafness

2. Cataracts

3. Congenital heart disease (commonly patent ductus arteriosus)

Other Clinical Features
  • Salt and pepper retinopathy (speckled retinal appearance)

 

  • Blueberry muffin lesions (bluish-red nodular lesions)
  • Microcephaly
  • Micrognathia
  • Developmental delay
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura
  • Jaundice
  • Hepatosplenomegaly

Diagnosis

Clinical findings and laboratory tests (rubella-specific IgM antibodies, rubella virus RNA detection)

Management

No specific antiviral treatment; prevention through rubella vaccination (MMR) before pregnancy

Complications
  • Developmental delay and cognitive deficits
  • Neurological sequelae (e.g., seizures)
  • Ophthalmic (e.g., cataracts)
  • Cardiac defects (e.g., patent ductus arteriosus)

Prevention

MMR vaccination prior to pregnancy is crucial to avoid CRS

Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) (Option A) can be transmitted to the newborn in utero, intrapartum, or perinatally. It causes severe complications, such as skin vesicles, eye findings (chorioretinitis, keratoconjunctivitis), and neurological sequelae (microcephaly/hydranencephaly) if acquired early, or skin, eye, mouth disease, encephalitis, or disseminated disease if acquired intrapartum.

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) (Option B) is the most common congenital infection with perinatal transmission, and it is associated with a variety of complications including hepatosplenomegaly, petechial rashes, jaundice, chorioretinitis, and microcephaly. Long-term sequelae include hearing loss.

Hepatitis B (Option D) has a significant risk of perinatal transmission, especially in cases with high viral load (HBeAg-positive mothers). Neonates infected with hepatitis B can develop chronic infection, which can lead to long-term liver complications.

questions.text: The causative agent of this condition is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pure red cell aplasia

Explanation:

  • The condition described is erythema infectiosum, also known as fifth disease, caused by Parvovirus B19. This virus is strongly associated with pure red cell aplasia, especially in certain high-risk groups.

 

Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)

 

Causative Agent

Parvovirus B19

Age Group

Predominantly 5 to 15 years (70% of cases)

Incubation Period

4–28 days

Transmission

Respiratory droplets; transmission rate 15–30% among close contacts

Clinical Features

Prodromal Phase: Low-grade fever, headache, mild URTI symptoms

Rash: "Slapped-cheek" erythema on face, spreading as a lacy pattern to trunk and extremities

Management

Self-limiting disease

Complications

Aplastic Crisis: Severe anemia due to erythropoiesis suppression in chronic hemolytic anemia

Arthropathy: Arthritis/arthralgia, more common in adults

Fetal Infection: Nonimmune fetal hydrops, stillbirth risk

Other Manifestations: Papular purpural gloves and socks syndrome, myocarditis

 

Childhood Exanthems: The "First to Sixth" Diseases

Order

Disease

Pathogen

Clinical Features

First Disease

Measles

Measles virus (Paramyxoviridae)

High fever, Koplik spots, maculopapular rash spreading cephalocaudally (head to trunk and limbs).

Second Disease

Scarlet Fever

Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A)

Sandpaper-like rash, strawberry tongue, pharyngitis.

Third Disease

Rubella

Rubella virus (Togaviridae)

Mild fever, maculopapular rash starting on face, posterior auricular lymphadenopathy.

Fourth Disease

Duke’s Disease

Staphylococcus aureus or unknown

Rare; characterized by mild rash and fever.

Fifth Disease

Erythema Infectiosum

Parvovirus B19

"Slapped cheek" rash, lacy erythematous rash on trunk and limbs, mild fever.

Sixth Disease

Roseola Infantum/ Exanthem subitum

Human Herpesvirus 6/7 (HHV-6/HHV-7)

High fever followed by maculopapular rash after fever subsides.

 

Gingivostomatitis (Option A): Commonly caused by Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV-1), not Parvovirus B19.

Molluscum contagiosum (Option C): Caused by a poxvirus, presenting with dome-shaped, umbilicated papules.

Kaposi sarcoma (Option D): Associated with Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), typically seen in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., HIV/AIDS).

questions.text: A young man is brought to the hospital with high-grade fever and altered consciousness. On examination, the patient had neck rigidity and pain when bending the neck. A lumbar puncture was performed and it showed a WBC count of 1500 cells/µL, the majority being neutrophils, elevated pressure with protein of 120 mg/dL, and a glucose level of 70 mg/dL (blood glucose level - 300 mg/dL). How will you manage the index case?
questions.solution:
The young man’s presentation of high-grade fever, altered consciousness, neck rigidity, and lumbar puncture findings (elevated neutrophils, high protein, low glucose relative to blood glucose, and elevated pressure) is suggestive of bacterial meningitis. The first line of management involves the administration of a third-generation cephalosporin along with vancomycin for 10-14 days.

 

Bacterial meningitis in neonates and children

Common Causes by Age Group

Neonates

Pre-school Children

Older Children
  • Escherichia coli (gram-negative bacilli)
  • Group B streptococci
  • Listeria monocytogenes
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae

Clinical Features
  • Lethargy
  • Fever
  • Hypothermia
  • Seizure
  • Headache
  • Stiff neck
  • Irritability
  • Drowsiness
  • Vomiting

Diagnosis

Lumbar puncture (CSF analysis):

  • CSF Appearance: Cloudy or purulent
  • CSF Pressure: Elevated
  • WBC Count: Elevated (1000-5000 cells/µL)
  • Predominant Cells: Neutrophils
  • Protein: Elevated (>100 mg/dL)
  • Glucose: Low (<40 mg/dL or <40% of blood glucose)
  • Gram Stain: Positive for bacteria

Treatment
  • Immediate Management: Start with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover pathogens.
    • Third generation cephalosporins (Ceftriaxone) along with vancomycin x 10 to 14 days
  • Adjunctive Therapy: Inj. Dexamethasone started 1-2 hr before antibiotics and continued for 48 hrs - Prevents cytokine mediated CNS injury.
  • Supportive Care: Manage complications like raised intracranial pressure and seizures.

Prevention
  • Vaccines for H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae. No vaccine currently exists for group B meningococcal infections.
  • Chemoprophylaxis: Close contacts of individuals with meningococcal meningitis should receive prophylactic antibiotics like rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin or ceftriaxone to reduce the risk of secondary infections.
    • Rifampicin - 600 mg 12 hourly for 2 days
    • Ciprofloxacin - 500 mg single dose
    • Azithromycin 500 mg single dose
    • Ceftriaxone - 250 mg Intramuscular single dose

Complications

Hearing loss (common with H. influenzae and S. pneumoniae), seizures, memory impairment, decreased intellectual function, hydrocephalus, sepsis, and risk of death

  • The patient's presentation with fever, cough, red eyes, and running nose with the image showing Koplik spots on buccal mucosa is suggestive of measles.

Mumps (Option A) primarily presents with parotid gland swelling and does not have the characteristic progression of respiratory symptoms and rash seen in this case. The absence of parotid involvement makes this diagnosis unlikely.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents with a cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. The total leukocyte count is >50,000 cells/μL. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Azithromycin

Explanation:

  • An infant presenting with paroxysmal cough, apnea, and marked leukocytosis (>50,000 cells/μL) is suggestive of pertussis (whooping cough). Azithromycin is the first-line treatment for pertussis in all age groups.

Pertussis

Causative agent

Bordetella pertussis, Bordetella parapertussis

Secondary attack rate

100%

Clinical Stages
  1. Catarrhal (1-2 weeks): Cold-like symptoms, worsening cough
  2. Paroxysmal (2-6 weeks): Severe cough, "whoop", vomiting
  3. Convalescent (1-4 weeks): Recovery

Complications

Apnea, Otitis media, Pneumonia, Pulmonary hypertension, Cardiogenic shock, Hemorrhage, Seizures, hernia and malnutrition.

Diagnosis

Clinical signs, nasopharyngeal swab culture, PCR, serology.

Differential Diagnosis

Adenoviral infection, TB, foreign body inhalation, airway compression.

Management

 

First-line antibiotics for treating pertussis:

  • Azithromycin is the first-line treatment for pertussis in all age groups.
  • Erythromycin and clarithromycin are alternative treatments but are C/I in <1 month old due to risk for infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS). (Option D)

Alternative antibiotics: For patients allergic to macrolides or there is unavailability of azithromycin, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole) may be used, but it is C/I in <2 months old (due to the risk for kernicterus) (Option C)

Timing of treatment: Antibiotics are most effective during the catarrhal stage

Isolation: Patients diagnosed with pertussis should be isolated from others, especially vulnerable populations like infants and the elderly, for at least 5 days after starting antibiotics.

Prevention

DTaP vaccine (Diphtheria, Tetanus, and Pertussis): Given to children under 7 years of age as part of routine childhood vaccinations.

 

Tdap vaccine (Tetanus, Diphtheria, and Pertussis): Recommended for adolescents, adults, and pregnant women (preferably between 27 and 36 weeks gestation) to provide protection and reduce transmission to infants.

Amoxicillin (Option B) is not used in pertussis because it is ineffective against Bordetella pertussis in the nasopharynx.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and a rash spreading from the face, behind cheeks and buccal mucosa to other body parts. On examination, Koplik's spot is present. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Measles

Explanation: The clinical scenario of fever, rash spreading from the face to other body parts, and the presence of Koplik's spots in a child points towards a diagnosis of measles.

Measles:

Aspects

Description

Causative agent

Measles (rubeola) is a highly communicable childhood exanthematous illness caused by the measles virus, an RNA virus from the Paramyxoviridae family.

Transmission

Contact with droplet aerosols (through the respiratory tract or conjunctiva)

Pathogenesis

Primary viremia occurs, resulting in infection of the reticuloendothelial system, followed by secondary viremia, which results in systemic symptoms.

Incubation period

8-12 days

Period of infectivity

From 3 days before to 4 days after the rash onset

Clinical manifestations
  • Common in preschool children
  • Prodromal phase: Fever (before rash), rhinorrhea, conjunctival congestion and a dry hacking cough.
  • Koplik spots, pathognomonic for measles, appear on the 2nd or 3rd day of illness as grey-white, sand-like lesions with surrounding erythema on the buccal mucosa opposite the lower second molars.

Rash

The erythematous maculopapular rash in measles appears on the 4th day, starting behind the ears, along the hairline, and posterior cheeks, then spreading to the rest of the body over the next 2-3 days.

Management

Symptomatic and conservative (antipyretics, maintenance of hygiene, ensuring adequate fluid and caloric intake, and humidification).

 

Rubella (Option B) presents with low-grade fever, a centrifugal macular rash, and prominent lymphadenopathy, with tiny rose-colored lesions on the soft palate (Forchheimer spots), which are different from Koplik's spots seen in measles.

Varicella (Option C) presents with a characteristic pruritic rash that evolves in stages (macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts) and does not present with Koplik's spots.

Mumps (Option D) presents with fever, headache, parotitis, and ipsilateral auricular pain, with a morbilliform rash that may occur, but it is not associated with Koplik's spots.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby comes with complaints of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Congenital rubella syndrome

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of deafness, cataract, and patent ductus arteriosus in an infant is most suggestive of Congenital rubella syndrome.

Congenital rubella
  • Rubella (German measles) is a mild disease in infants and children but can cause congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) if contracted during pregnancy.
  • The risk is highest in the first trimester, especially within the first 8 weeks.

Pathogenesis

  • Viremia is most intense from 10 to 17 days after infection.
  • Viral shedding is from day 10 of infection up to 2 weeks.

Risk of Defects by Gestational Age
  • Highest in the first 12 weeks of gestation and decreases significantly thereafter, with defects being rare after 20 weeks.

Clinical features of congenital rubella syndrome
  • Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) (most common)
  • Vision problems (cataracts, glaucoma, salt and pepper retinopathy).
    • Cataracts are the most common ocular abnormality associated with congenital rubella.

\

  • Heart defects (patent ductus arteriosus > pulmonary artery stenosis (right > left) > ventricular septal defect)
  • Low birth weight
  • Neurological issues (microcephaly, intellectual disabilities, encephalitis, behavioral issues)

Chronicity and Complications
  • Chronic presence of the virus can cause ongoing damage
  • The risk of progressive rubella panencephalitis (PRP) years later is a rare complication.
  • Less common complications: Growth retardation, hepatitis, bone lesions.
  • Risk of diabetes and thyroid dysfunction

Diagnosis
  • Rubella IgM enzyme immunosorbent assay (detects antibodies)
  • Viral isolation (growing the virus from samples)
  • Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) (detects viral RNA)

Management
  • No specific treatment for CRS; supportive care is key
  • Early intervention for complications (e.g., hearing loss) is crucial

Prevention
  • Standard with droplet precaution in hospitalized cases
  • Rubella vaccination RA 27/3 live attenuated vaccine (MMR or MMRV with varicella) effectively prevents rubella and CRS
  • MMR vaccine has a 95% efficacy after one dose and 99% after two doses
  • Vaccination side effects: fever, rash, joint pain

Considerations for Pregnant Women
  • Immunoglobulin may be considered if pregnancy is not terminated, though it does not guarantee prevention of fetal infection

 

Congenital herpes simplex virus infection (Option A) can be transmitted in utero, during delivery, or in the neonatal period. Intrauterine infection leads to skin vesicles, eye abnormalities such as chorioretinitis and keratoconjunctivitis, and neurological complications like microcephaly or hydranencephaly. Infection acquired at birth can present as localized disease affecting the skin, eyes, and mouth, as encephalitis, or as disseminated infection resembling neonatal sepsis.

Congenital toxoplasmosis (Option B) results from maternal infection, particularly during pregnancy. The severity depends on the timing of transmission, with early pregnancy infections leading to more severe outcomes, while later infections tend to be milder. The classic presentation includes a triad of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications.

Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection (Option C) is often acquired when maternal infection occurs during pregnancy, with the highest transmission risk in the third trimester. Affected newborns may have growth restriction, microcephaly, periventricular calcifications, chorioretinitis, developmental delays, hepatosplenomegaly, hemolytic anemia, and thrombocytopenia. While many neonates are asymptomatic at birth, sensorineural hearing loss is a common long-term complication.

questions.text: The perinatal transmission of infection shows the spectrum of anaemia, possibly myocarditis, high-output cardiac failure, and ascites. Identify the causative agent.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Parvovirus B19

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation described, including anemia, myocarditis, high output cardiac failure, and ascites, in the setting of hydrops fetalis, points to Parvovirus B19 infection.
  • Parvovirus B19 is the causative agent of erythema infectiosum (also known as Fifth disease), and its perinatal transmission can cause serious complications.

 

Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)

Causative Agent

Parvovirus B19

Age Group

Predominantly 5 to 15 years (70% of cases)

Incubation Period

4–28 days

Transmission

Respiratory droplets; transmission rate 15–30% among close contacts

Clinical Features

Prodromal Phase: Low-grade fever, headache, mild URTI symptoms

Rash: "Slapped-cheek" erythema on face, spreading as a lacy pattern to trunk and extremities

Management

Self-limiting disease

Complications

Aplastic Crisis: Severe anemia due to erythropoiesis suppression in chronic hemolytic anemia

arthropathy: Arthritis/arthralgia, more common in adults

Fetal Infection: Nonimmune fetal hydrops, stillbirth risk

Other Manifestations: Papular purpural gloves and socks syndrome, myocarditis

 

Childhood Exanthems: The "First to Sixth" Diseases

 

Order

Disease

Pathogen

Clinical Features

First Disease

Measles

Measles virus (Paramyxoviridae)

High fever, Koplik spots, maculopapular rash spreading cephalocaudally (head to trunk and limbs).

Second Disease

Scarlet Fever

Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A)

Sandpaper-like rash, strawberry tongue, pharyngitis.

Third Disease

Rubella

Rubella virus (Togaviridae)

Mild fever, maculopapular rash starting on face, posterior auricular lymphadenopathy.

Fourth Disease

Duke’s Disease

Staphylococcus aureus or unknown

Rare; characterized by mild rash and fever.

Fifth Disease

"Slapped cheek" rash, lacy erythematous rash on trunk and limbs, mild fever.

Sixth Disease
